column2: Maureen, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My dermatologist prescribed this medication for treatment of Lichens Planoplaris Frontal Alopecia -- basically hair loss when hair follicles die after enough scarring due to skin inflammation...a harmless health risk, but still something most women want to prevent. Prednisone was also prescribed for the first four weeks of treatment with the dose stair stepping down as the Plaquenil built up in my system. I was three days away from ending the Prednisone when I began to feel sick -- lethargic, fever, sore/constricted throat, swollen tongue and a ripe rash that bloomed first on my lower back. While waiting for my doctor to return my call, this rash had spread around my torso. I was sent to my primary doc to determine if this was an allergic response to medication or a viral/bacterial infection. My primary felt it was drug allergy and gave me a shot of cortisone with advice to also take Bendryl and keep my dermatologist appointment scheduled for the next day. I awoke sicker than before with a 103 degree fever and a virulent, itchy rash that had spread to cover my body like a racer-back swimsuit! Plus, my body seemed to be swelling from the inside with enlarged waist and breasts. My dermatologist said because the steroid shot hadn't knocked the rash back but seemed to enhance it that she felt the reaction might really be viral or bacterial after all and sent me back to my primary for further diagnostics. I was able to get blood tests and a strep test by early afternoon and found out the next morning that I was healthy except for this reaction and prescribed another round of steroids -- oral and topical -- to treat the drug allergy. It has been two days and the rash is finally subsiding, though slowly, and my temperature is normal. I am concerned now about how long full recovery will take -- I have a vacation trip planned in less than two weeks-- plus will I have now an ongoing need for steroids and if I have any permanent damage to organs.

column9: An extremely rare allergic reaction to this drug called Stevens-Johnson Syndrome very nearly killed me sixteen years ago. A reheumalogist declared my lupus to be 'wildly out of control'and prescribed Plaquenil. He said that if my face should happen to turn 'red like a lobster', to call him immediately. After two doses, I knew that something was very wrong and went to see him that same morning. He took one look at me, handed me a prescription for a massive amount of Demerol and told me to go home, that I would be very ill. (He was a real compassionate guy!) That was at 10am. At that point, I looked like I had a bad case of acne. By 10pm, I did look like a lobster and could not drink enough water. I was in pain all over; it felt like my skin was being pulled off my body. By 3am, my skin WAS starting to slough off like a third-degree burn over at least half of my body. The pain was excruciating. The local emergency room admitted me as an inpatient and got three IV's running-two for fluid rehydration and one for a drip Demerol. Solumedrol was added later in the day. Very few practitioners know what Stevens=Johnson Syndrome is, much less have seen it at any stage. Sadly, it is not as rare as it used to be. Many of the new pharmaceuticals are causing a variation of SJS that involves damage to the linings of internal organs. If you or your family medical history runs toward allergies or auto-immune diseases, do your homework before popping that new pill. It could save you or someone you love a very painful traumatic experience, maybe even save a life.
